case_name: Bengal Chemical Pharmaceutical Works Limited v. Bengal Chemical Mazdoor Union

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 125 and 164 of 1958 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 125 and 164 of 1958. Appeals by special leave from the Award dated August 26, 1957,

facts.text: Award dated August 26, 1957 by Fifth Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal in Case No. VIII-264/56.

anchor.surface_text: from the Award dated August 26, 1957, of the Fifth Industrial Tribunal -at West Bengal in Case No. VIII-264/56. C. Issacs and S. N. M

facts.text: Dispute between Bengal Chemical Pharmaceutical Works Limited, Calcutta, and Bengal Chemical Mazdoor Union, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: in the matter of a dispute between Messrs. Bengal Chemical Pharmaceutical Works Limited, Calcutta, and their employees, represented by Bengal Chemical Mazdoor Union, Calcutta.

facts.text: Government of West Bengal referred dispute on September 13, 1956 to Second Industrial Tribunal under s.10 of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of West Bengal by its order dated September 13, 1956, referred the following dispute between the parties referred to above to the Second Industrial Tribunal under s. 10 of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947

facts.text: Dispute question: Is the demand of the employees for increase in Dearness Allowance justified? If so, at what rate?

anchor.surface_text: hereinafter referred to as the Act. Is the demand of the employees for increase in Dearness Allowance justified ? If so, at what rate?. The said Act was amended- by the Industrial Disputes

facts.text: Government transferred dispute on April 9, 1956 from Second to Fifth Industrial Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: On April 9, 1956, the Government made an order transferring the said dispute from the file of the Second Industrial Tribunal to that of the Fifth Industrial Tribunal.

facts.text: Fifth Industrial Tribunal made award on August 26, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The Fifth Industrial Tribunal, after making the necessary inquiry, made the award on August 26,1957, and it was duly published in the Calcutta Gazette on September 26, 1957.

facts.text: Award published in Calcutta Gazette on September 26, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: made the award on August 26,1957, and it was duly published in the Calcutta Gazette on September 26, 1957. As a mistake had crept in, the award was modified

facts.text: Award modified on November 29, 1957 and published same day.

anchor.surface_text: As a mistake had crept in, the award was modified by the Tribunal by its order dated the 29th November, 1957 and the modified award was published in the Calcutta Gazette on the 29th November, 1957.

facts.text: Tribunal awarded increase of Rs. 7 in dearness allowance on pay scale up to Rs. 50 and Rs. 5 above Rs. 50.

anchor.surface_text: Under the award the Tribunal held that there was a rise in the cost of living index and that to neutralise the said rise the employees should get an increase of Rs. 7 in dearness allowance on the pay scale up to Rs. 50 and Rs. 5 on the pay scale above Rs. 50.

facts.text: Company filed Civil Appeal No. 125 of 1958 against the award.

anchor.surface_text: On that basis the dearness allowance payable to the employees was worked out and awarded. The correctness of the award is questioned in these appeals. The Company preferred Civil Appeal No. 125 of 1958

facts.text: Union filed Civil Appeal No. 164 of 1958 against the award.

anchor.surface_text: The Company preferred Civil Appeal No. 125 of 1958 against the award in so far it was against it and the Union preferred Civil Appeal No. 164 of 1958 in so far it went against the employees.

facts.text: Previous award made on April 26, 1951 by Tribunal between same parties.

anchor.surface_text: the previous award made by the Tribunal between the same parties on April 26, 1951, and confirmed by the Labour Appellate Tribunal by its order dated August 30, 1951,

facts.text: Previous award confirmed by Labour Appellate Tribunal on August 30, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: confirmed by the Labour Appellate Tribunal by its order dated August 30, 1951, had not been terminated in accordance with the provisions of s. 19(6) of the Act

facts.text: Industrial Disputes Amendment Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1956 (36 of 1956) came into force on August 28, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The said Act was amended- by the Industrial Disputes Amendment Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1956 36 of 1956 , which came into force on August 28, 1956.

facts.text: Government transfer order dated April 9, 1957 from Second to Fifth Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: 1 The order dated April 9, 1957, made by the Government transferring the dispute from the file of the Second Industrial Tribunal to that of the Fifth Industrial Tribunal was illegal

facts.text: Agreement between parties dated September 15, 1954 on pay scales and DA.

anchor.surface_text: the terms of the agreement entered into between the parties on September 15, 1954. The dispute between the parties had an earlier origin and apart from the present reference,

facts.text: Agreement clause: existing rate of D.A. will prevail unless substantial change in working class cost of living index.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the dearness allowance, it was stated in cl. 11 of the agreement as follows The existing rate of D. A. will prevail unless there is a substantial change in the working class cost of living index,

facts.text: Tribunal found rise in cost of living index between 1954 and 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Under the award the Tribunal held that there was a rise in the cost of living index and that to neutralise the said rise the employees should get an increase

facts.text: Working class cost of living index at 344.1 in August 1954, rose to 400.6 in May 1957 (Exhibit 3).

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of Exhibit 3, the Tribunal held that the working class cost of living index stood at 344.1 in August 1954 and it rose to 400.6 in May 1957, with the result that there was a rise of 56 points,

facts.text: Supreme Court delivered judgment on January 28, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. January 28. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO, J.-These appeals are by Special Leave -from the Award by Shri G. Palit,

facts.text: Court held transfer order of April 9, 1957 valid under amended Act.

anchor.surface_text: It must, therefore, be held that the Government acted well within its powers in transferring the dispute pending before the Second Industrial Tribunal, to the Fifth Industrial Tribunal.

facts.text: Court held previous 1951 award superseded by 1954 agreement.

anchor.surface_text: The award must be deemed to have been superseded by the new agreement. In this context the crucial words existing rate of D. A. , on which both the learned Counsel relied, could have only one meaning.

facts.text: Court did not permit Company to raise plea on termination of 1951 award under s.19(6).

anchor.surface_text: As the question raised depends upon elucidation of further facts, we do not think that we would be justified in allowing the Company to raise the plea before us, and we, therefore, do not permit them to do so.

facts.text: Tribunal allowed 75% neutralization of rise in cost of living index.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the overall picture, it came to the conclusion that full neutralisation of the deficiency as a result of rise in the cost of living index by dearness allowance could not be permitted and therefore allowed them only 75 per cent.

facts.text: Supreme Court confirmed the award and dismissed appeals with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we confirm the award of the Tribunal and dismiss the appeal with costs. The learned Counsel, appearing for the Union, did not press the appeal No.

facts.text: Union did not press its appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Counsel, appearing for the Union, did not press the appeal No.

facts.text: Industrial Disputes Amendment Act, 1957 (18 of 1957) deemed s.2 into force on March 10, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section (2) of s. I of the Amending Act 18 of 1957 says that s. 2 shall be deemed to have come into force on the 10th day of March, 1957.

facts.text: Previous dispute references: four references and awards, last dated April 3, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The dispute between the parties had an earlier origin and apart from the present reference, there were as many as four references and four awards, and the last of them was dated April 3, 1951.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal confirmed April 1951 award on August 30, 1951 with modifications.

anchor.surface_text: The Company preferred an appeal against that award to the Labour Appellate Tribunal-, Calcutta, which, with some modification, confirmed the award of the Tribunal on August 30, 1951.

holdings.text: Article 136 confers discretionary power to grant special leave; interference with tribunal awards only in cases of violation of natural justice, grave injustice, important principle of industrial law, or exceptional circumstances; same standard applies at special leave and appeal stages.

anchor.surface_text: under Art. 136 of the Constitution vis-a-vis the awards of Tribunals. Article 136 of the Constitution does not confer a right of appeal to any party from the decision of any tribunal,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Preserves self-contained nature of Industrial Disputes Act, promotes industrial peace via quick resolutions; limits cannot vary by stage as leave is ex parte and without full facts; follows precedents like Pritam Singh.

holdings.text: Government acted well within its powers in transferring the dispute pending before the Second Industrial Tribunal to the Fifth Industrial Tribunal on April 9, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: It must, therefore, be held that the Government acted well within its powers in transferring the dispute pending before the Second Industrial Tribunal, to the Fifth Industrial Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.33B(1) read with s.2(r) substituted by 1957 Amendment Act (deemed in force March 10, 1957) includes pre-March 10, 1957 tribunals, empowering transfer to s.7A tribunal; s.30 of 1956 Act unaffected.

holdings.text: Company not permitted to raise plea that 1951 award not terminated under s.19(6) as reference lacks jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: As the question raised depends upon elucidation of further facts, we do not think that we would be justified in allowing the Company to raise the plea before us, and we, therefore, do not permit them to do so.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plea not raised before Tribunal, no issue framed or argument advanced despite opportunity; depends on further facts like notice service; new plea barred in Supreme Court.

holdings.text: 1954 agreement superseded 1951 award; 'existing rate of D.A.' refers to rate as on September 15, 1954; cost of living index rise calculated from 1954 base.

anchor.surface_text: The award must be deemed to have been superseded by the new agreement. In this context the crucial words existing rate of D. A. , on which both the learned Counsel relied, could have only one meaning.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement self-contained, settles charter of demands, reviewed entire situation per preamble; replaces award for covered matters; textual meaning of 'existing' as of agreement date.

holdings.text: No interference with Tribunal's findings on change in circumstances justifying new award, reliance on prior awards, and computation of dearness allowance amount.

anchor.surface_text: Contentions 3, 5 and 6 raise pure questions of fact. The Tribunal, on the consideration of the entire material placed before it, came to the conclusion that there was change of circumstances which entitled the employees to claim an increase in their dearness allowance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pure questions of fact; Tribunal weighed material, balanced employee needs against industry difficulties allowing 75% neutralization; no perversity or Art.136 grounds.

holdings.text: Company cannot challenge relevancy of Exhibit 3 (cost of living index) for first time in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, we do not think that we are justified to allow the learned Counsel for the Company to make out a new case for the first time before us, upsetting the Tribunals basis for calculation and involving further and different calculations.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No challenge, cross-examination, or argument before Tribunal on Exhibit 3 applying only to menials; new case barred; supports factual finding.

holdings.text: Tribunal's award confirmed; appeals dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we confirm the award of the Tribunal and dismiss the appeal with costs. The learned Counsel, appearing for the Union, did not press the appeal No.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All contentions rejected; award on dearness allowance increase justified and correctly computed.
